entry.title: [CW] Tuesday marked [the death of Raymond Briggs](https://www.theguardian.com/books/2
entry.content:
Tuesday marked [the death of Raymond Briggs](https://www.theguardian.com/books/2022/aug/10/snowman-author-raymond-briggs-dies-aged-88), one of England's greatest graphic novelists, most widely known for [The Snowman](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZE9KpobX9J8) and [Father Christmas](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VkoejIzlITA).
While his life and death aren't culture wars material per se, I wanted to mention his passing because his work was *immensely* influential on me as a kid. Specifically, when I was about 7 years old, I read his graphic novel [When The Wind Blows](https://readcomiconline.li/Comic/When-the-Wind-Blows), and accidentally saw [the TV adaptation](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9pJKdTqYijY) a few years later. In a departure from his previous work aimed at children, this was a "comic book" about nuclear war. Even more specifically, it's about an elderly English couple who follow every bit of government advice, and slowly, painfully die of radiation sickness in the wake of a nuclear attack on the UK.
I cannot emphasise enough how much anxiety and trauma this caused me as a child. I was lucky enough to avoid a religious upbringing, but suddenly, I became aware of civilisational-level threats and the horror of the apocalypse. I literally took weeks off school because I was vomiting from fear of nuclear attack, a condition that only eased when puberty hit and I became worried about much more sensible things like not having a large enough penis.
While at some level I resent Briggs (and my parents!) for exposing me to such existential horror at such a young age, I'm also very grateful. I do think the world is a safer place in virtue of this kind of protest comic. It also set in motion a lifelong coping strategy for me - when faced with something terrifying, I resolved to learn as much as possible about it, so that the emotional was replaced by the intellectual. In my late prepubescent years, I became fascinated by nuclear weapons and prepping, and to this day, I make sure to keep potassium iodide pills in the house. Somehow by turning horrors into intellectual problems, they lose their terror.
In any case, Raymond Briggs's work helped make me who I am today. May the man rest in peace, and his work continue to (appropriately, within reason) traumatise generations yet to come.
